Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
 How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
 For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
 Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.

If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616)204-6992.

INVESTIGATION:
Rule Code & CCI R 400.4127 Staff to resident ratio.
Section (4) When residents are asleep or otherwise outside of the direct
Description supervision of staff, staff shall perform variable interval, eye-on
checks of residents. The time between the variable interval checks
shall not exceed fifteen minutes.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation The youth at the facility sneak out of the facility windows and go on the
roof. One youth went AWOL on 11/03/22 and the facility did not know
until the following day. Youth is placed at the facility for issues with
running away and the expectation is that he would be supervised.
Youth outside of the facility are leaving vapes on the facility premises
for youth at the facility.
Investigation Administrator 1 was interviewed over the phone on 11/16/2022. She
was informed of this new investigation. Administrator 1 provided
information on staffing and as well as procedures for third shift work at
the facility and documentation related to the incident. She stated that
there was only one youth currently placed at the facility. It was
discussed that the incident in question revolved around a “dummy” that
Youth A had formed with pillows and blankets under his comforter in an
attempt to distract staff from his running away from the facility.
2

Administrator 1 described the third shift policies and training that the
facility uses and stated that they have not required staff to see anything
specific for a youth that appears to be covered completely by their
bedding while sleeping.
Staff 1 was interviewed during an unannounced face-to-face visit on
11/16/2022. She stated that she was the first shift staff who discovered
that Youth A had left the facility sometime overnight on the night of the
incident. She stated that her shift started before the youth wake up at
about 8:30 AM. She stated that she went in to wake Youth A up and
was surprised because Youth A was usually awake by the time, she
entered the room. She stated that she poked her head in the room and
said something to the effect of “Hey, time to get up” and did not get a
response for about five minutes. Staff 1 recalled getting her coworker
Staff 2 in order for them to both go in the room together. Staff 1 stated
that when she went in the room and pulled the blankets back, she
discovered that Youth A was not in the bed. At this point Staff 1 stated
that she and Staff 2 walked through the rest of the house and
immediately went through their communication tree to alert appropriate
people that Youth A had a AWOL’ed, including calling Administrator 1
and Probation Officer 1 as well as Central dispatch. Staff 1 described
the alarm system that the facility utilizes. She stated that all the
windows are alarmed as well as doors to the bedrooms for the youth.
Staff 1 opened several windows and doors in order to provide examples
of the chime that can be heard throughout the house. Staff 1
hypothesized that Youth A timed the alarm of opening his window with
another door opening, or a shift change in order to sneak away and not
be noticed. Staff 1 showed the specific bedroom in which Youth A was
placed prior to his leaving, which is downstairs. The bedroom window
provides adequate egress and is level with the ground outside. Staff 1
confirmed that the windows are not locked in this facility.
In regards to allegations of youth that were sneaking out of their
windows onto the roof, Staff 1 stated that she had heard the current
youth placed stating that he has done this before, but believed he said
this in a joking manner. Staff 1 stated that when she heard Youth B
joking about this, she made sure to tell him that this was not
appropriate and that it should not be spoken about lightly.
Staff 1 stated that she has not heard of any allegations or concerns
about Vape pens being hidden on the grounds of the facility for youth to
get into their possession. She referred to an incident a few weeks prior
when two youths believed they saw someone outside one evening, but
staff quickly went outside and did not see anyone near the house or in
the adjacent woods next to it.
4

Youth B was interviewed on 11/16/2022 during an unannounced face-
to-face visit at the facility. He stated that he did not know what was
going on with Youth A until the morning that it was discovered Youth A
had left the facility. He stated Youth A said to him the prior day that he
was thinking about running away, but he did not believe staff overheard
this nor did he really believe Youth A himself. Youth B stated that he
does not know how Youth A would have run away because he feels
that third shift staff are pretty active during the night. Youth B stated this
because he said he frequently gets woken up by staff moving around
the house and briefly coming into the rooms to do their nightly checks.
He stated that he can hear the alarm throughout the house. Youth B
was asked about allegations that youth were climbing out of the
windows and getting out to the roof at night and he stated that he was
only joking about that the other day and he had heard another youth
state that in a previous time placed at the facility approximately a year
ago. Youth B denied ever climbing out of his window to get onto the
roof at night. Youth B also stated that he has never seen or been
concerned about individuals leaving vape pens outside the home for
youth to get, but stated that he heard another previously placed youth
talking about that happening back in 2010.
Youth A's mother/Complainant was interviewed over the phone on
1/09/2022. She reported that her son is now out of state, but she had
contact with him in the days after he was found after his AWOL from
the facility. She stated that he told her he had gone to bed for the night
and attempted to time his window opening by hearing another door
open within the house. Youth A's mother stated that he did not offer
any more details than that. She also stated that he had reported to her
that other youth were going out onto the roof at night, as well as
procuring vapes from outside sources at the facility. Youth A's mother
stated that she did not bring up these concerns with the facility after
hearing them because she thought they may have been untrue and did
not know how to bring them up.
Probation Officer 1 was interviewed on 01/09/2022 over the phone.
She stated that she still works with Youth A and that he is in a
residential program in Arizona. Probation Officer 1 stated that she knew
about the allegations that Youth A attempted to time his window
opening with another door in the facility in order to run away. She
stated that she had immediate communication with the facility after they
discovered Youth A was gone the next morning. Probation Officer 1
stated that she recalled hearing Staff 1 state that Youth A had said he
was going to bed early the night prior, and that Staff 3 admitted to not
actually seeing Youth A’s face when doing the nightly bed checks.
Probation Officer 1 stated that she has worked with the facility
numerous times and has one other youth run away, but she did not
4

have any concerns about how that incident transpired. Probation Officer
1 stated that she had never heard allegations about the vaping or youth
climbing onto the roof as well. Probation Officer 1 reiterated that she
had very good communication with the facility prior to and after Youth
A‘s run away and did not have any concerns with using them again.
Staff 3 was interviewed over the phone on 01/09/2023. She confirmed
that she was the third shift staff responsible for the night in question.
Staff 3 stated this felt like a very normal night with only a couple youths
placed in the facility. She stated that her training has always been to
open the door of a bedroom, or peek inside if the door is already slightly
open, and look to see if youth are in their beds. Staff 3 stated that it has
never been asked of her to make sure that she sees a body part or a
face of a youth while doing this check. Staff 3 recalled seeing what she
believed to be Youth A sleeping as curious because he did not move
over the course of the night, but she did not act on that any further as
per the facilities training for third shift. Per the facility’s Policies and
procedures handbook dated 03/15/2022 “The bedroom checks section
will start as soon as the youth go into their rooms. These are done
sporadically in 15-minute intervals. Bedroom checks section does not
correspond to a singular room, instead it is a continuation of the many
room checks done per night.” Staff 3 stated that the hallway light near
the downstairs bedroom stays on all night and provides enough light to
see well enough into the bedroom, so no flashlights are needed. She
stated that she has oftentimes accidentally woken up youth as she
opens doors to look inside their rooms. Staff 3 stated that there was not
any chance that Youth A was able to get onto the roof of the facility
because he was in one of the downstairs bedrooms. Staff 3 also
denied any knowledge about the allegations that someone was leaving
vape pens around the grounds for youth to have without staff's
knowledge. Staff 3 stated that her normal routine during third shift is
that she sits in the living room near the stairs to the downstairs
bedrooms as well as upstairs bedrooms. She stated that she sits in a
chair angled specifically so that she can hear and see as much as
possible. Staff 3 stated that she sometimes has the television on but
keeps the volume at two in order for it to be as quiet as possible. Staff 3
also stated that she checks the facility's alarm system at the beginning
of each shift. She stated that in her 10 years of working third shift at the
facility, she has seen the alarm system malfunction only once or twice.
Both of those instances involved alarms going off that did not need to
be going off as opposed to alarms not going off when they should. Staff
3 did not believe that there was a chance that the alarm did not go off
when Youth A ran away, but that he was likely smart enough to time it
well so that it was unnoticed.
Documents that were reviewed over the course of this investigation:
4

- Facility Policies and Procedures. The section describing “Midnight
duties” states the following: “The bedroom checks section will start
as soon as the youth go into their rooms. These are done
sporadically in 15-minute intervals. Bedroom checks section does
not correspond to a singular room, instead it is a continuation of the
many room checks done per night.”
- Security cameras. The facility’s security system has cameras
pointing at the front entry room, living room, classroom, kitchen and
the hallways to the bedrooms. There are no cameras that capture
anything inside the bedrooms or the exterior where Youth A would
have exited the building.
- Picture of the bedroom of Youth A was provided showing pillows
and blankets formed under the comforter to simulate someone
sleeping in the bed.
- Case file for Youth A. Youth A did not have a history of AWOL
concerns prior to placement in this facility.
- Midnight shift duties documentation from the night of 11/03/2022
when Youth A ran away from the facility. Requirements from CCI
Rule 400.4127 (4) were met with checks made within 15 minutes of
each other for youth’s bedrooms.
Analysis From interviews with staff, youth and other individuals responsible to
Youth A as well as documentation reviewed, it is found that a violation
of CCI Rule 400.4127 (4) occurred because staff was not able to have
“eyes on” checks of Youth A after he had formed a “dummy” under his
comforter and ran away from the facility.
Conclusion Violation Established
4

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or MISEP requirements and/or contract/policy.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the that
the current license status be continued.
